author: By Michael Gold
title: Best, Worst and Most Awkward Lines at the Al Smith Dinner
description: Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris both delivered remarks, Ms. Harris via taped video and Mr. Trump in person in a ballroom in Manhattan.
content: The two people running for president in one of the most pivotal and divisive elections in American history both tried to be funny at a Catholic charity event on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Buying a Cottage and Finding a ‘Time Capsule’
description: A couple renovated a house in Darien, Conn., and retained much of what the previous owners had left behind.
content: Vickie and Neal Brauweiler live with their two teenage children in what Mr. Brauweiler, a 54-year-old software engineer, likes to call the “cheap seats” of affluent New Canaan, Conn. The couple were looking for an investment property that they could rent out and possibly take over themselves one day. They found it, for $625,000, in nearby Darien, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Impeachment of Kenya’s Deputy President Could Signal Further Turmoil
description: It’s the first impeachment under the country’s new Constitution, but some are now calling for a similar move against President William Ruto.
content: Kenya’s Senate has voted to impeach the country’s deputy president, an unprecedented move that risks stirring a major political crisis and potential unrest in an East African nation widely viewed as a stable democracy in an increasingly volatile region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Power Outage Plunges All of Cuba Into Darkness
description: The Cuban government had just announced emergency measures to reduce electricity use — then the power went out across the entire nation.
content: Cuba’s power grid failed and the entire nation plunged into darkness Friday, less than a day after the government stressed the need to paralyze the economy to save electricity in the face of major gasoline shortages and large-scale, regular outages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: FKA twigs’s Electro-Pop Enticement, and 8 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Haley Heynderickx, Cymande, Bonzie and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Outside the Office, Sparks Fly Between Colleagues
description: Taylor Burt was working at BarkBox, surrounded by adorable dogs, when she found herself distracted by someone she thought was even cuter: Mayank Shah.
content: Taylor Suzanne Burt was at work and fully in her element when she met Mayank Kishor Shah in September 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Kellen Browning
title: A Candidate for U.S. Senate Says He Was Shot in War. Was He?
description: Tim Sheehy, a Republican running for U.S. Senate in Montana, says he has a bullet in his arm from Afghanistan. But new questions have been raised about his account.
content: In a book and in his campaign for the U.S. Senate in Montana, Tim Sheehy has talked about a bullet lodged in his forearm — an injury he says he suffered as a Navy SEAL during a firefight in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
title: Sinwar’s Final Moments: On the Run, Hurt, Alone, but Still Defiant
description: Israeli forces had been steadily closing in on Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader, for weeks before he was cornered and killed in a ruined house in the Gaza Strip.
content: At the end, the fearsome militant leader who had helped unleash a vicious war seemed barely a threat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 18, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 18, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about pandas arriving at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington misstated how long it had been since pandas were at the National Zoo. The zoo had no pandas for about a year following the death of the bear Hsing-Hsing in 1999; November 2023 did not mark the first time in more than 50 years the zoo had no pandas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Renewed Efforts to Reach a Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: Also, a power outage plunged all of Cuba into darkness. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: President Biden said today that the killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar offered “an opportunity to seek a path to peace” in the Middle East. Speaking in Berlin, where he met with European leaders, Biden said he would send Secretary of State Antony Blinken to Israel in the coming days to discuss a plan to end the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: In Rare Move, Judge Changes Mind After 27 Years and Frees Brooklyn Man
description: Judge Frederic Block said his ideas about punishment had evolved since he sentenced Walter Johnson to five life terms in 1997. At age 90, he decided to take action.
content: In 1997, Walter Johnson stood before Judge Frederic Block in a Brooklyn federal courtroom after being convicted of robbery, cocaine possession and witness tampering, just the latest in a troubling series of crimes that involved guns, drugs and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: It Was Love After First Flight
description: Lindsay Bennie heeded Victoria Williams’s call for a Valentine’s date, but they were hundreds of miles apart. Once they finally met, “our connection was instantaneous,” Ms. Bennie said.
content: “I’ll take you out,” Lindsay Nicole Bennie wrote in a direct message more than six years ago to Victoria Ashley Williams after Ms. Williams tweeted about wanting a woman to be her Valentine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: In this month’s picks, a shy vampire in Canada comes of age, two men in India spar over a parking spot and a Chilean secretary dreams of life as a killer.
content: Stream it on Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
title: Veterans Dept. Investigating Acadia Healthcare for Insurance Fraud
description: Several federal agencies are investigating whether the large chain of psychiatric hospitals held patients without medical justification.
content: The Veterans Affairs Department is investigating whether Acadia Healthcare, one of the country’s largest chains of psychiatric hospitals, is defrauding government health insurance programs by holding patients longer than is medically necessary, according to three people with knowledge of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: At Comic Con, Emergency Tailors Keep Cosplayers in Character
description: Armed with glue guns, Popsicle sticks, safety pins and more, a hub of costume repairers stands at the ready to make sure all goes according to fantasy.
content: When cosplayers descend on New York Comic Con, they’re looking to meet their favorite creators and show off their outfits — but they often end up in need of costume triage. Armed with glue guns, zip ties, Popsicle sticks and safety pins, the Paladins of Cosplay come ready to fix wardrobe malfunctions — like a dangling shoulder pad, an imploding jetpack or any number of hazards that costumed fans face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: arpeggio
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word arpeggio has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 20 in “The 40 Best Songs of 2024 (So Far)” by Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Charges Against Deaf Black Man Punched by Phoenix Police Are Dropped
description: The man, Tyron Scott McAlpin, who also has cerebral palsy, was repeatedly punched and shocked with a Taser by the police during an arrest in August. The arrest is under investigation.
content: A prosecutor in Arizona announced this week that she had dropped charges against a deaf Black man who has cerebral palsy after she reviewed details of his arrest, during which police officers repeatedly punched him and shocked him with a Taser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
title: Microsoft and OpenAI’s Close Partnership Shows Signs of Fraying
description: The “best bromance in tech” has had a reality check as OpenAI has tried to change its deal with Microsoft and the software maker has tried to hedge its bet on the start-up.
content: Last fall, Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, asked his counterpart at Microsoft, Satya Nadella, if the tech giant would invest billions of dollars in the start-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden, in Germany, Urges Unwavering Support for Ukraine
description: The president, in a trip to Berlin that lasted barely a day, also joined Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in expressing new optimism about the prospect for peace in the Middle East.
content: Sidelined at home in the waning days of the campaign to succeed him, President Biden made a brief return to the global spotlight on Friday, rallying allies in support of Ukraine, and basking in praise from the German government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: These Americans Say They’ll Move Abroad if Their Candidate Loses
description: We spoke with Americans who are packing up and moving out.
content: Good evening! Lots of people muse about leaving the country if an election doesn’t go their way. My colleague, Ronda Kaysen, who covers real estate, spoke with Americans who say they’re actually planning to. Plus, we look at what it’s like to listen to a whole speech by former President Trump. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman, Rowan Niemisto and Diane Wong
title: Powerful A.I. By 2026? + Uber’s C.E.O. on the Robotaxi Future + Casey’s TikTok Test
description: “Check your calendar, Kevin, that is in 14 months.”
content: This week, the A.I. company Anthropic has Silicon Valley rethinking the timeline for artificial general intelligence. In addition to releasing a new safety policy, the company’s chief executive, Dario Amodei, laid out a vision of how A.I. could help cure cancer, mental illness and mitigate climate change in the near future. We consider his most surprising claims and what this means for the acceleration of the technology. Then, the Uber chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, joins us in the studio to discuss his company’s new partnership with Waymo, the autonomous vehicle company, and the future of that industry. And finally, leaked court documents reveal exactly how many TikTok videos you need to watch to get hooked on the app. So, Casey puts the number to the test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Death of Hamas’s Leader
description: Yahya Sinwar is dead. Could this be a turning point?
content: The killing of Yahya Sinwar — the chief architect of the Oct. 7 attack — is the most tangible victory that Israel has yet been able to claim in its more than yearlong war against Hamas. Almost as soon as the Oct. 7 attack happened, Israeli leaders vowed to hold Sinwar accountable. So long as he was still directing Hamas’s operations from the tunnels of Gaza, Israel could not credibly claim to have achieved its goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: What We Know About the Execution Pending in the Shaken Baby Case
description: With his execution on hold, Robert Roberson is set to testify at a Texas House hearing about his conviction, which was based in part on a questionable diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome.
content: The execution of Robert Roberson, an autistic Texas man convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter, was halted at the last minute after a novel legal move by a bipartisan group of Texas House members who questioned the diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome that helped lead to his conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Sinwar’s Death Was a Victory for Israel. But Can the U.S. Persuade It to ‘Take the Win’?
description: Assassinating Yahya Sinwar was Israel’s Osama bin Laden moment. But getting a cease-fire deal done in the last three months of the Biden presidency is a much bigger reach.
content: Within hours of the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar on Thursday, President Biden and his aides scrambled to design one last push for a broad de-escalation of violence in the Middle East: a cease-fire and hostage deal in Gaza, a pullback from Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon, a confident declaration of victory by Israel that might allow it to forgo a major retaliation against Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Charged Up Over Electric Cars
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 18, 2024
content: “They don’t have to beat Tesla, they just have to beat everybody else.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Denk
title: At 150, Charles Ives Still Reflects the Darkness and Hope of America
description: This pioneering composer is not the easiest to love. But while he explores the poison of American nationalism, his music also offers an antidote.
content: Sunday is the 150th anniversary of the composer Charles Ives’s birth, and the most fitting way to celebrate would be to bang your fists on the table and rail against the damned closed-mindedness of classical music, with its lazy dependence on a predictable canon. But honestly, that’s old news; a lot of the classical community is already doing that. Would Ives be satisfied by the current state of things? Hard to say. Improvements have been made but not, I suspect, enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: JD Vance and the Fight for Pennsylvania’s Catholic Voters
description: The Republican vice-presidential nominee is the only Catholic on either national ticket. His politics resonate with many white conservative Catholics.
content: Three dozen Catholics from “Lebo,” as the Mt. Lebanon area of Pittsburgh is called, packed into Colleen Oxenreiter’s living room on a recent Friday evening. Lebo is a heavily Catholic neighborhood, and her home was the one with a giant Trump sign in the yard, by her pumpkins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: The Breakthrough Drug to Conquer Addiction: Ozempic?
description: Early data suggests GLP-1 drugs, renowned for their ability to assist in weight loss, may have a powerful effect on treating addiction.
content: In late 2016, Steven Klein realized that he’d lost control over his drinking and stimulant use. He became sober that December, with help from 12-step meetings. But he also struggled with overeating, which he views as another addiction. Stress from the pandemic caused him to gain more than 40 pounds during his medical residency. In 2022, he decided to try Mounjaro, part of a new class of medications like Ozempic and Wegovy that are proving effective in treating obesity and diabetes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Sinwar: What Is the Future of Gaza?
description: Responses to the killing of the Hamas leader. Also: Guarding against authoritarianism; medical dramas; expressing sympathy to mourners; October light.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: CVS Ousts C.E.O. as Sluggish Growth Spooks Investors
description: Shares of the health care conglomerate dropped after the sudden departure of Karen Lynch and a downbeat update on the state of the company’s finances.
content: CVS Health abruptly ousted its chief executive, Karen S. Lynch, on Friday as the pharmacy and health care conglomerate struggled with sluggish growth and faced pressure from investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: When Grief Goes Viral
description: On TikTok, some users posted videos of themselves learning about Liam Payne’s death in real time. At a time when the cameras are always rolling, it’s not so unusual.
content: Amelie Bowen and a friend were filming a dance video for TikTok in her bedroom on Wednesday when Ms. Bowen’s mother entered the room to deliver sad news. Liam Payne, former member of the boy band One Direction, had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK to Name Our Dog for a God?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on canine naming conventions.
content: My family recently adopted a rescue dog. As we were going through a long list of possible names for our pup, two of the more charming possibilities were Odin (the king of the gods in ancient Norse mythology) and Zeus (the leader of the gods in ancient Greek mythology). I was concerned that naming our dog for someone else’s deity would be disrespectful. After all, would it be OK to name our pet Yahweh or Allah? I once had a friend with a cat named Shiva; I was a child at the time, so I thought nothing of it, but I wonder about it now. Does it make a difference whether anybody still worships the ancient Norse and Greek gods, as opposed to the gods and prophets of the very active Judeo-Christian, Islamic or Hindu religions? For that matter, is the answer different depending on which active religion we’re talking about? — Pablo Halpern
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamal Michel
title: Gaming’s Uneven Progress Toward Diverse Female Figures
description: A vocal group that says women in video games are being defeminized wants to return to 1990s babes like Lara Croft.
content: The intergalactic bounty hunter in the sci-fi video game Metroid was outfitted with a sleek helmet, red and orange armor and a deadly arm cannon. But it’s what was underneath that was emblematic of the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Will Campaign With the Obamas Next Week
description: Barack and Michelle Obama will make their first campaign appearances alongside Kamala Harris at rallies in Georgia and Michigan.
content: Here come the Obamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: How to Stop Being a People Pleaser
description: We have some useful tips from experts. But no worries if you’re not ready!
content: When I was in my early 20s, the apex of my people-pleasing years, I dated an aspiring poet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: A ‘New Day’? Justices Step Back, Slightly, From an Aggressive Climate Stance.
description: The Supreme Court’s decision to not temporarily block an E.P.A. rule this week signals ‘rising influence’ of Justice Barrett, one analyst said.
content: The conservative-majority Supreme Court has taken an aggressive stance against many environmental rules in recent years, but three small victories for regulators this month have left some analysts wondering whether a shift is underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: The Ultrarich Descend on Paris as Art Basel Comes to Town
description: The inaugural edition at the restored Grand Palais featured works at price levels never seen before at Paris’s fall art fair.
content: Americans flocked to the city in droves. A warm fall sun shone through the vast glass roof. The dealers brought their very best pieces. And the Art Basel brand did what it does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Erica L. Green
title: Why Harris Remains Unlikely to Break From Biden on Israel and Gaza
description: Her advisers say the empathy she has expressed for Palestinians as vice president should not be confused with any willingness to break from U.S. foreign policy toward Israel as a presidential candidate.
content: Last December, Vice President Kamala Harris flew to a climate conference in Dubai and quickly huddled with the leaders of three Arab nations to discuss Israel’s war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: A Sherrod Brown Ad Seizes on an Unwise Remark About Women and Abortion
description: Bernie Moreno, his Republican rival, said women older than 50 are “crazy” for caring about abortion rights. A series of Ohio women who fit that description have much to say in response.
content: The re-election campaign of Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, has been running this 30-second ad attacking his Republican opponent, Bernie Moreno, on television stations across his state at a cost of nearly $1.3 million so far, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: When Your Wedding Day Is Also Election Day (or Close to It)
description: Fall weddings are increasingly common. But what happens when your nuptials also take place close to a contentious election?
content: Shannon Hendrickson and Drew Fitzmaurice have thought through every detail of their wedding, which will take place on Nov. 2 in Scituate, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Venue Celebrates the Sound of the Bronx
description: The Bronx Music Hall is the first new independent music venue in the borough in more than 50 years.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll get a look at the Bronx Music Hall, the first brand-new music performance space to open in that borough in more than 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats’ Report Calls Trump Hotel Business Unethical and Unconstitutional
description: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee said the former president overcharged the Secret Service and accepted money from officials and people who were seeking pardons and appointments.
content: House Democrats on Friday accused former President Donald J. Trump of accepting “hundreds of unconstitutional and ethically suspect payments” through the Trump International Hotel in 2017 and 2018, moving weeks before the election to remind voters of the ethical issues raised by his refusal to divest from his businesses while in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Homeowners Tap Into Their Rising Home Equity
description: Balances on home equity lines of credit have risen along with home equity loans. Popular reasons for borrowing include home renovations and repairs and debt consolidation.
content: American homeowners have accrued hundreds of thousands of dollars in home equity and they’re increasingly borrowing against that value, even though interest rates remain high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Judge Releases Redacted Trove of Evidence in Trump Election Case
description: The former president’s legal team had objected to any release of material, saying it would amount to election interference.
content: A federal judge on Friday ordered the release of a heavily redacted trove of evidence supporting the contention by federal prosecutors that former President Donald J. Trump illegally sought to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: U.S. Charges Indian Official in New York Assassination Plot
description: The United States and Canada have worked together to investigate what they say is the Indian government’s campaign against Sikh separatists.
content: Federal prosecutors have charged a man they identified as an Indian intelligence officer with trying to orchestrate from abroad an assassination on U.S. soil — part of an escalating response from the United States and Canada to what those governments see as brazenly illegal conduct by a longtime partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman, James Poniewozik, Elyssa Dudley, Frannie Carr Toth and Diane Wong
title: How a Blouse, a Bandage or a Handshake Might Sway a Voter
description: Our critics decode the political subtexts that matter in 2024 — and beyond.
content: Times readers often express surprise — and sometimes even outrage — in response to political coverage by our culture critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘It’s Florida, Man’ Reveals the Lives Behind Bizarre News Stories
description: The HBO series uses familiar comedic actors in cheeky re-enactments of real Florida events, most of them subjects of past viral news reports.
content: “It’s Florida, Man,” premiering Friday at 11 p.m., on HBO, takes a “Drunk History” approach to the intimacy and portraiture of “How To With John Wilson.” It uses familiar comedic actors in cheeky re-enactments of real events, but those events are all personal sagas; they are obscure and strange, sometimes disturbing and sometimes enchanting — and all very Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: These Undecided Michigan Voters Really Aren’t All That Undecided
description: Many people I spoke to seemed reluctant to admit — even, perhaps, to themselves — that they were really going to vote for that person.
content: Cindy Jager was the lone worker on duty in the crammed aisles of an old-fashioned variety store overflowing with hardware and party supplies and fake pumpkins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Self-Driving System Will Be Investigated by Safety Agency
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it was looking into what Elon Musk’s electric car company called the full self-driving system.
content: Tesla’s plan to build fleets of self-driving cars suffered a setback on Friday when the main federal auto safety regulator said it was investigating whether the technology was to blame for four collisions, including one that killed a pedestrian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: In Montauk, N.Y., an $18 Million Listing for a Secluded Stone House
description: The two-story home sits on a bluff overlooking the Atlantic. It was once owned by the interior designer Tony Ingrao.
content: High above a rocky bluff overlooking the Atlantic, on the far eastern end of Montauk, N.Y., sits a rustic stone house visible mostly to fishermen and water enthusiasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Thomas Tuchel and the Moral Maze
description: An outcry over the hiring of a German to lead England’s national team was predictable. But don’t dismiss every objection out of hand.
content: As a rule of thumb, it pays to look at the cast of characters already arrayed on one side of an argument before deciding to join them. When that list starts with Nigel Farage, swallows up Sam Allardyce and eventually sprawls across the editorial board of The Daily Mail, it should, really, serve as a burning red flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Peacekeeping Force in Southern Lebanon Will Remain, U.N. Official Says
description: Israel has demanded that the force, known as UNIFIL, pull out. But all the countries contributing troops and the U.N. Security Council decided unanimously that UNIFIL should stay.
content: U.N. peacekeepers in Lebanon have experienced a series of deliberate attacks by the Israeli military in recent days, but the peacekeeping force will maintain its positions along the border despite Israeli pressure to withdraw, according to a spokesman for the force, known as UNIFIL.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What I’ve Learned Interviewing More Than 200 New York Times Journalists
description: Over the past four years, I’ve written more than 100 articles that explain our journalism. What I learned might surprise you.
content: For the past four years, I’ve been the audience for a series of master classes, delivered by more than 200 of the best minds in journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler, Ryan Mac and Theodore Schleifer
title: How Tech Billionaires Became the G.O.P.’s New Donor Class
description: Elon Musk and a group of Silicon Valley allies have built a shadow campaign to put Donald Trump back in office.
content: Last February, the billionaire financier Nelson Peltz summoned a group of about 20 wealthy, predominantly Republican donors and a handful of G.O.P. strategists to dinner at his $334 million waterfront estate in Palm Beach, Fla. There were plenty of people in the room who had publicly disavowed former President Donald Trump after the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol — Peltz among them — but it was pretty clear now that he was going to be the candidate, and it was time to get onboard and figure out how to help him win. There were a lot of problems. An especially uncomfortable one was that a lot of donor money was going to paying Trump’s mounting legal bills rather than building a serious political campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Koren Shadmi
title: J. G. Ballard, Secret Agent in Suburbia
description: A graphic tribute to the British novelist who documented the blight and brutality of the sleepy London outskirts from the 1970s into the 2000s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg
title: What, Exactly, Is Eczema?
description: Experts explain what causes the common skin condition and how to deal with it.
content: When Oscar Brann imagined retirement, he pictured days spent fishing with his grandson, or doing yardwork at his home in Skowhegan, Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italian Judges Strike Down Request to Hold Migrants in Albania
description: The ruling was a major blow to the conservative government’s plan to have asylum claims heard in Albania instead of Italy.
content: Italian judges on Friday struck down a request by the government to hold a group of migrants in a detention center in Albania, ordering that they should be taken to Italy, in a major setback for Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s flagship policy of outsourcing asylum requests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: Finding a Few Good Waves, and ‘Everything I Wanted’
description: Laura Baroni and Paul Keating, both avid surfers, met in Costa Rica and felt immediately connected, if not through their native languages.
content: In early 2022, Paul Thomas Keating and Laura Baroni each traveled to Costa Rica looking for something — but not necessarily for someone. The two kicked around the small beach town of Santa Teresa, on the western coast, for more than a month before laying eyes on each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Judge Orders DeSantis Administration to Stop Threats Over Abortion-Rights Ad
description: The organization behind a campaign for an abortion-rights ballot measure sued the Florida governor’s administration over its threats of criminal prosecution against TV stations.
content: The administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida must stop threatening television stations with criminal prosecution for airing a political ad in favor of enshrining abortion rights in the state’s Constitution, a federal judge ordered on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Our Boundless Love for Big Sur May Be Killing It
description: Some 90 percent of the economy in this coastal California region relies on visitors. But overtourism, the high cost of living and most worrisome, the effects of global warming, create a future of uncertainty.
content: The 70 miles of California coastline that makes up the unincorporated area of Big Sur has a storied, almost mystical allure, largely thanks to its staggering beauty. With redwood forests, stunning Pacific views, winding rivers and natural hot springs, the area has for decades attracted celebrities, artists and millions of visitors. So many visitors in fact, that these days, Kirk Gafill, the president of the Big Sur Chamber of Commerce, estimates that 90 percent of the local economy is tourism-dependent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: The leader of Hamas is dead.
content: Yahya Sinwar, the powerful and elusive militant leader of Hamas who helped to plot the group’s devastating assault on Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, was killed in battle on Wednesday, the Israeli military said. A unit of trainee squad commanders unexpectedly encountered him in southern Gaza, Israeli defense officials confirmed yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Benjamin Oreskes
title: Nevada’s Senate Rivals Spar in a Debate Heavy on Policy and Light on Fireworks
description: Senator Jacky Rosen and her Republican challenger, Sam Brown, met for their only debate, focusing on the cost of living, abortion and other issues.
content: Sam Brown, the Republican vying for Nevada’s competitive Senate seat, entered the debate on Thursday night with a sizable deficit in surveys and a clear mission: rattle his Democratic opponent, Senator Jacky Rosen, and forcefully make the case that he was the candidate who would fight for working people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: It’s Time for Tagine
description: Nargisse Benkabbou’s hearty and fragrant beef tagine with green beans, olives and preserved lemons, that is.
content: Good morning. The texts are starting to come in, asking about Thanksgiving — who’s coming, how many birds, how many oysters, how many pies, what do we need? It’s exciting, a time to dream. I might fry a turkey this year, to go with the smoked one, to go with the oven-roasted one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Forgery, Fraud and Absinthe’s Enduring Mystique
description: Evan Rail’s “The Absinthe Forger” takes the reader on a picaresque tour through the world of vintage alcohol collectors in pursuit of a fraudster.
content: “If you tasted an absinthe that was supposed to have been made a century or more ago, would you even know what to look for?”  asks Evan Rail. It’s a key question driving his new book, “The Absinthe Forger: A True Story of Deception, Betrayal, and the World’s Most Dangerous Spirit,” which, along with the promised detective story, delivers a lively stand-alone seminar on temptation — as well as the culture and history of the much-maligned liquor and its reputation for causing madness and murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Camille Elemia
title: American Man Is Kidnapped and Taken Away on a Boat in the Philippines, Police Say
description: Four armed men shot and kidnapped a 26-year-old from Vermont from western Mindanao, the police said. He had been living in the area since May.
content: An American man living in the Philippines was shot and abducted from his home by armed men late on Thursday, according to the local authorities, who said on Friday that they were pursuing the kidnappers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Sinwar’s Death Is a Tricky Opportunity
description: A ceasefire is unlikely, but Israelis and Palestinians have new reasons for hope.
content: Reading the news that Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s pitiless leader, had been killed on Wednesday by Israeli forces in southern Gaza, I had the same sense of elation so many people felt when Osama bin Laden was killed. To take satisfaction in the violent end of another human being, even an enemy, is almost always wrong, but there are exceptions. Sinwar’s death — like bin Laden’s in 2011 or Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi’s in 2019 or Hassan Nasrallah’s last month — is among them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Sinwar’s Death Could Shake but Not Topple Hamas, Experts Say
description: Analysts call the killing of several Hamas leaders, including Yahya Sinwar, a deep blow to the Palestinian militant group, but expect it to keep fighting.
content: He was there from the early days of Hamas, rose through the ranks to lead the organization and equipped it for the deadliest assault on Israel in its history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: After Hush-Money Verdict, Trump Tried to Silence Stormy Daniels Again
description: Donald J. Trump was convicted in May of covering up a hush-money deal with Stormy Daniels. Just two months later, his lawyer offered another deal for her silence.
content: In May, Donald J. Trump was criminally convicted of covering up a hush-money deal with the porn star Stormy Daniels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Evidence for a Big Youth Gender Gap and a Right Turn for Young Men
description: Young men are much more Republican than young women, the best data suggests, and may wind up backing Donald Trump.
content: In the year’s first wave of New York Times/Siena College battleground polls back in May, the No. 1 predictor of whether someone had defected from Joe Biden was whether the respondent was Middle Eastern or North African — a sign of the political toll of the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Left Out of Trump’s New York Myth: A Reliance on Big Tax Breaks
description: In the new biopic “The Apprentice,” much is made of Trump’s tutelage under the venal fixer Roy Cohn. But the film shrewdly locates the secret of his success: tax abatements.
content: “The Apprentice,” the film dedicated to illuminating the Donald Trump origin story, made its debut at the Cannes Film Festival last spring to an eight-minute standing ovation and opened in American theaters last weekend to a bleak $1.6 million box-office tally and a predictably damning appraisal from its protagonist, who called it “fake,” “classless” and a “politically disgusting hatchet job.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: California Man Is Charged With Drugging and Sexually Assaulting 9 Women
description: The man, Michael DiGiorgio, is also charged with murdering one of the women, who died after being drugged, prosecutors said.
content: A 50-year-old California man has been charged with drugging and sexually assaulting nine women at his homes in the oceanfront cities of Hermosa Beach and Redondo Beach, and of murdering one of them who died after being drugged, prosecutors announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: What Will Become of Yahya Sinwar’s Body?
description: Uncertainty surrounds the fate of the Hamas leader’s corpse as experts say Israel will likely try to avoid having his resting place become a shrine.
content: The death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar was confirmed Thursday by Israeli authorities, but questions remain about the location of his body and what may happen to it in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Orionids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
description: This event is linked to Halley’s comet, and occurs as another comet, Tsuchinshan-ATLAS, remains visible. But a nearly full moon could interfere with some views.
content: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can observe only a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Lackluster Growth Continues, Signaling Why Beijing Acted on Economy
description: New data shows the challenges facing Chinese policymakers trying to stimulate an economy marked by falling prices, weak consumer spending and a housing market crash.
content: The Chinese economy continued to grow at a lackluster pace over the summer, according to data released on Friday, underscoring the urgency of the government’s recent attempts to bolster growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: In This Town, a Rape Trial Hits Painfully Close to Home
description: The town of Mazan, where Gisèle Pelicot was drugged and raped by her husband and strangers, has been shaken by the revelations. “It feels a bit like it’s in our family,” one resident said.
content: Mazan is a postcard of Provence — a small medieval village perched on a hill, surrounded by vineyards, in view of the windswept Mount Ventoux rising in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu, Chevaz Clarke and James Surdam
title: Trump’s Claims That Blame Migrants: False or Misleading
description: The Trump campaign has consistently pointed to unauthorized immigration as the cause of a series of problems it says plagues the country. That is rarely actually the case.
content: To former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, the root cause of many of the issues in the United States is simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Art Adviser to the Elite Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud
description: Lisa Schiff acknowledges stealing millions from major collectors who trusted her to buy them fashionable art.
content: A leading art adviser whose clients have included Leonardo DiCaprio, and who was accused by the government of bilking her clients of millions, pleaded guilty on Thursday in federal court in Manhattan to one count of wire fraud, for stealing $6.5 million from people who trusted her to buy art for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Danielle Kaye
title: What’s at Stake in a Strained Microsoft-OpenAI Partnership
description: The alliance between the technology giant and the company behind OpenAI has been hugely consequential — but a disruption could shake up the A.I. race.
content: Few partnerships in the technology world in recent history have been as transformative as Microsoft’s alliance with OpenAI, which paired a computing giant with a start-up that is among the leaders in artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert and Euan Ward
title: Israel Destroys Nearly All of a Lebanese Village, Photos and Videos Show
description: About two dozen buildings were demolished in the village, which The Times identified as Mhaibib, just over a mile from Israel’s northern border.
content: The Israeli military destroyed most of a village in southern Lebanon this week with a series of explosions, according to videos verified by The New York Times and satellite images. About two dozen buildings were demolished in the village, which The Times identified as Mhaibib, just over a mile from Israel’s northern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Michael Gold and Katie Glueck
title: In Michigan, Harris and Trump Fight for Blue-Collar and Arab Voters
description: Campaigning in the battleground on the same day, Kamala Harris cast herself as a friend to union workers while Donald Trump sought to capitalize on anger over the war in Gaza.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump converged on Michigan on Friday as they fought for the small pool of undecided voters and Arab Americans who could decide a battleground state that has shot toward the top of the priority list for both campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Draw Sports Fans to an Art Museum? That’s the Goal.
description: Through design objects and artwork by former athletes, “Get in the Game” at SFMOMA examines the central, and often provocative, role that sports occupy in American culture.
content: As museums experiment with ways of attracting new visitors beyond a niche audience of art lovers, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has assembled an ambitious exhibition anchored in a subject with wide appeal: sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France Struggles to Dry Out From Flash Flooding
description: Heavy rainfall and swollen rivers unleashed torrents of brackish water that cut off roads, swept away cars and swamped buildings.
content: Central and southern France were recovering on Friday from flooding that lashed the areas on Thursday, after heavy rainfall and swollen rivers unleashed torrents of muddy water that cut off roads, swept away cars and swamped buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Former Olympic Snowboarder Wanted by F.B.I. on Murder and Drug Charges
description: Ryan Wedding, 43, was indicted with 15 others on charges of trafficking drugs into Canada and the U.S., the authorities said. He is believed to be living in Mexico.
content: A Canadian snowboarder who competed at the 2002 Winter Olympics is wanted by the F.B.I. on charges of conspiring to ship hundreds of kilograms of cocaine into Canada and the United States and on suspicion of orchestrating multiple murders, the U.S. attorney’s office for the Central District of California announced in a statement on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Jeanna Smialek
title: How Is the Economy for Black Voters? A Complex Question Takes Center Stage.
description: Donald J. Trump has been talking up his economic record for Black voters. The legacy of the last eight years is complicated.
content: The 2024 election could be won or lost on the strength of the Black vote, which could in turn be won or lost based on the strength of the American economy. So it is no surprise that candidates are paying a lot of attention — and lip service — to which of the past two administrations did more to improve the lives of Black workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Sara Ruberg
title: 200 Years Later, Still Trying to Define the Midwest
description: From the geographic boundaries to the values and friendliness, people have debated what defines the region essentially since it was labeled the Midwest. It has taken on a renewed urgency this election year.
content: State fairs. Frozen custard. The jingle for the home-improvement chain Menards. Rolling corn fields, sweatshirts with shorts, steel plant smokestacks and swing-state politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: At the Grocery Store, Blinded by the Light of the ‘Health Halo’
description: The term refers to the perception that a food product is generally good for us based on a single claim, casting subliminal power over our diets and dollars.
content: In the airport terminal, two different grab-and-go snacks may appeal to travelers rushing to catch their flights: One is a candy bar, wrapped in chocolate and caramel. The other is also a bar wrapped in chocolate and caramel, but it’s “high in protein.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: Tegan and Sara and Their Catfishing Horror Story
description: “Fanatical,” an eye-popping film directed by Erin Lee Carr, details the bizarre 16-year ordeal that the duo and their fans endured.
content: The turn-of-the-century internet was organized not around content selected for us by algorithms, but around shared interests that we sought out. Whether you loved a band or were devoutly religious or had questions about your sexuality, someone had made an AOL chatroom or a message board or a LiveJournal community where you could meet people like you. It was often invigorating and life-affirming, especially if you felt lonely in the real world. It seems like the exact opposite of today’s personality- and ad-driven internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Binelli
title: Has Winnipeg’s Greatest Filmmaker Gone Hollywood?
description: In a directorial career defined by alluring strangeness, Guy Maddin’s new comedy is radical for being almost … normal.
content: At some point during the production of his first film, “The Dead Father,” Guy Maddin made one of his most consequential decisions as a director. It was the early 1980s, in Winnipeg. Maddin was around 26 and had only recently started watching movies seriously, thanks to a friend who had been sneaking him into film classes at the University of Manitoba. When he had the notion to make his own black-and-white short, he reckoned it prudent to pick up a book on filmmaking. The one he chose mentioned three distinct types of lighting, so when shooting began, Maddin dutifully aimed all three of the lights he’d procured at his lead actor’s face. The three lights produced three nose shadows. He unplugged one light, then another. The third left a single nose shadow. It looked like a Hitler mustache, but Maddin just told the actor to move his head until it disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘The Warriors’ Hooked Lin-Manuel Miranda at 4. Now Comes the Album.
description: He collaborated with Eisa Davis to make a concept album inspired by the 1979 movie. One big change: the main gang is made up of women.
content: “The Warriors,” a 1979 film about a group of gang members fighting their way home to Brooklyn from the Bronx, isn’t the most brutal movie ever made, but it’s not exactly Sesame Street either — when it was first released, it was blamed (on pretty flimsy evidence) for inciting violence. And yet, somehow, Lin-Manuel Miranda found himself watching the movie when he was 4, thanks to a friend’s older brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How Los Angeles Is Trying to Keep Homeless People Off the Streets
description: The city relies on an army of case managers to help homeless people stay in motels and on the path toward finding an apartment.
content: The day was shaping up to be another long one for Freddy Bauer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Ben Hubbard, Alexandra E. Petri, Robert Jimison and Jessica Metzger
title: The Death of Yahya Sinwar, and Execution Halted in Shaken Baby Case
description: Plus, closing time for Kmart.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: When Opportunity Leaves, the Government Has Two Choices
description: Like people, places can fall on hard times. Do they also deserve help?
content: If you tramp through the woods of New England and upstate New York, you will see stone walls marking the borders of farms that have been abandoned for a century or two. You may see the foundation of a small house, the entrance to a mine or the crumbling walls of a mill. The people left when the opportunity to make a living ran out, leaving behind nothing but stones, bricks and ghosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Ronen Bergman, Mooj Zadie, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Eric Krupke, Paige Cowett, M.J. Davis Lin, Chris Haxel, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Israel Kills The Leader of Hamas
description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, was killed by Israeli forces in Gaza. What does that mean for cease-fire talks?
content: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, played a central role in planning the deadly assault on Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, that set off the war in Gaza. His killing was a major win for Israel, and prompted calls from Israeli leaders for Hamas to surrender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Fire in Oakland Hills Prompts Evacuations Under Gusty Conditions
description: Firefighters in Northern California were responding to a blaze that burned two homes and 15 acres.
content: A brush fire erupted in Oakland, Calif., on Friday, forcing the evacuation of hillside neighborhoods and the brief closure of a major highway as high winds threatened to spread the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Mets and Yankees Fans Actually Getting Along? Say It Ain’t So.
description: Bitter rivals are suddenly paying each other compliments, at least until there’s a Subway Series, if that happens. “It’s weird,” said the longtime Yankees announcer.
content: It started gradually, as the Mets became the most compelling story in baseball over the last couple of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: It Is ‘All About the Fish’ on Park Ave.
description: Avid and influential anglers turned out to honor Bob Rich Jr. at the Bonefish & Tarpon Trust’s annual gala in Manhattan.
content: On Tuesday night, on a quiet stretch of Park Avenue, some of the most illustrious figures in fly fishing, marine science, conservation and frozen food gathered to celebrate one of the things that brings them all together — the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
content: Based on the time the serial killer Rodney Alcala appeared on “The Dating Game” in the midst of his crime spree, Anna Kendrick directs herself as the woman Alcala is competing for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: There Is No Precedent for Something Like This in American History
description: This is no ordinary election, and we cannot act like it is.
content: Toward the end of his tenure, Gen. Mark Milley, who was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from 2019 to 2023, told Bob Woodward of The Washington Post that Donald Trump was a fundamental threat to the safety and integrity of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Do You Splurge On?
description: Whether it’s a pair of sneakers, new makeup, a concert or something else, when you have some extra cash, how do you spend it?
content: What was the last item or experience you splurged on? That is, something you didn’t necessarily need, but really wanted, and were willing to spend some extra cash to get. Did it make your life better?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Local Hangout Dad and Daughter Found Special (for Different Reasons)
description: Jocelyn DeGroot-Lutzner grew up four blocks from Ephream Seyoum in West Philadelphia. But the two didn’t meet until she applied for a job at his family’s Eritrean restaurant.
content: Jocelyn Rose DeGroot-Lutzner was thinking about her father when she wandered into the West Philadelphia restaurant Dahlak in 2013 to apply for a bartending job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: In Swing Districts, Republicans Lean Into Anti-Crime Message to Court the Center
description: Representative Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican in a tough re-election race in Oregon, is using a law-and-order pitch to appeal to a broad swath of voters and blunt concerns about the G.O.P. agenda.
content: Thirty minutes south of Portland, as rain pattered down from gray skies, Representative Lori Chavez-DeRemer, Republican of Oregon, was at a wedding venue railing against Democrats in her state for decriminalizing hard drugs and accusing them of failing to support local law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das
title: Facing Murder Plot Accusations, India Aids U.S. but Is Stern With Canada
description: In both cases of plans targeting Sikh separatists, suspicions of New Delhi’s involvement have arisen. That has put India in a tight diplomatic position.
content: In a week of geopolitical intrigue, in which Canada broadened its accusations that India was plotting to kill Sikh citizens on its soil and the United States provided incriminating evidence in a similar case, one episode caused a furious rift and the other a more judicious response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: $2 Million Homes in Munich
description: A country house with a pool southwest of the city, a two-bedroom condo with a balcony, and a modern two-bedroom duplex not yet completed.
content: With its sloping roof, wood balcony and shutters, and vine-covered walls, this four-bedroom family home about 25 miles southwest of central Munich evokes a traditional Bavarian farmhouse. Built in 1989, the house has been through several upgrades, including a designer kitchen and new heating in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Sinwar’s Death Highlights Israel’s Long Quest for Deterrence
description: Israel’s killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar is the latest expression of Israel’s belief that regional acceptance will be achieved only through strength.
content: A quarter century before Israel was founded, the Zionist leader Zeev Jabotinsky articulated an idea that has come to define the way Israelis protect their country. A Jewish state, he wrote in 1923, would succeed only by projecting enough strength to force its enemies to accept it as a permanent reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Much of the Emerald Isle Is an Ecological Desert. He’s Trying to Change That.
description: Eoghan Daltun rewilded his land in West Cork and wants more of Ireland to do the same.
content: Is Ireland really all that green? Ecologically speaking, the answer is no, says Eoghan Daltun, a sculptor who restored a patch of native rainforest in the Beara Peninsula, on the country’s rugged southwestern coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: The 25-Year-Old Georgia Senate Candidate Looking to Unseat a Fake Trump Elector
description: Ashwin Ramaswami, a Democrat, was still in law school when he decided to run against State Senator Shawn Still, who was indicted with Donald Trump in the Georgia election interference case.
content: Ashwin Ramaswami, a Democrat running for a Georgia State Senate seat, grew up in a wealthy stretch of Atlanta suburbs transformed by the tech industry and waves of Indian American immigrants, like his parents, who have settled there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: After Becoming Housemates, Romance Entered the Picture
description: Jolyn Chen and Louis Lin went from middle school classmates to badminton partners to colleagues and, now, spouses.
content: The first time Jolyn Chen and Louis Lin became partners, it was as mixed doubles on Glen A. Wilson High School’s badminton team. It would be another two decades before they became life partners, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Franklin
title: This Novel for Young Readers Imagines Anne Frank Before Her Diary
description: “When We Flew Away” envisions what Anne might have been like before the cataclysm that shut her away and made her into “the voice of the Holocaust.”
content: “I want to go on living even after my death!” Anne Frank writes in one of the most unforgettable lines from her venerated “Diary,” the book that has done more than any other work of literature to give readers throughout the world a sense of what was lost in the genocide of six million Jews during the Holocaust. Some of those readers — who also happen to be writers — have responded to her call by turning her into a fictional character. A version of Anne who survives the war appears in at least three novels, most famously Philip Roth’s “The Ghost Writer” (1979), in which the young Nathan Zuckerman, Roth’s alter ego, encounters her as the attractive research assistant to his mentor and fantasizes about marrying her as a way of proving his Jewish bona fides to his parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: That Explains It
description: Jesse Cohn introduces six lively entries to the New York Times Crossword.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Hidden Politics of Disorder
description: The crime researcher Charles Fain Lehman discusses why people feel unsafe, even as violent crime rates have dropped.
content: During the pandemic, there was a rise in violent crime. But by 2023, violent crime was near its lowest level in over 50 years. But that year, Gallup found that 77 percent of Americans said they believed that crime was increasing. I hear that in my everyday life. People talk to me about their sense that where they live is less safe, and they’re mad about it. This was constant when I lived in San Francisco. It’s constant in New York, where I live now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,218
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 19, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Meet the Candidate: Elon Musk
description: The billionaire is spending a fortune to support former President Donald J. Trump. But at a town hall event in Pennsylvania, he looked an awful lot like a politician himself.
content: Is Elon Musk running for president?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Lebanon Issues Rare Criticism of Iran Over ‘Blatant Interference’
description: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, summoned Tehran’s envoy over reported comments by a senior Iranian official on a U.N. resolution deemed a precondition for a cease-fire.
content: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister accused Iran on Friday of meddling in the country’s affairs, opening up a rare diplomatic spat after Iran’s parliament speaker remarked that his country was ready to help negotiate terms to bring about a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Yes, Ambassadors Can Get Away With Murder
description: Diplomatic immunity is one of the oldest and most respected rules of international law.
content: On Monday, the Canadian government accused India’s High Commissioner, (the equivalent of an ambassador in commonwealth countries), and five other diplomats of participating in a vast criminal conspiracy that used homicide and extortion to silence critics of India living in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Trump Among New York’s Elites at a Charity Dinner: It Got Awkward
description: There were grudge matches and sycophancy in equal measure at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. “Isn’t it just exciting, what’s going on,” Donald Trump said.
content: Donald J. Trump and the assorted fat cats to whom he was speaking seemed to be processing many complicated emotions all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman, Bilal Shbair and Jim Tankersley
title: Hamas Says Its Demands Are Unchanged as Biden Pushes for Gaza Cease-Fire
description: A top deputy to the killed Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar vowed that his “banner will not fall” and that the group would hold to its cease-fire conditions.
content: A top Hamas official vowed on Friday that the killing of the group’s leader, Yahya Sinwar, would change nothing for its war with Israel, saying that it would fight on even as President Biden pressed for a deal to stop the conflict in the Gaza Strip and free the remaining hostages there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: An Invitation to the Dance, Simple and Subtle
description: DD Dorvillier’s solo at the Chocolate Factory evokes a dream state as it digs into the same river of dance twice.
content: As soon as DD Dorvillier walked onto the stage of the Chocolate Factory Theater on Thursday night, you knew you were in the presence of somebody long immersed in her craft, capable of doing a lot with a little. Through the simple act of standing still and surveying the audience, she seemed to light a spark in the bare warehouse space, her enigmatic gaze bristling with minute shifts of awareness. It was the subtlest invitation into a dance made with the lightest touch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Chianti Classico Riservas to Find Right Now
description: These longer-aged wines were once notable for being too oaky and powerful. Now, producers are letting the gorgeous purity of the sangiovese grape shine through.
content: I could not have imagined, 10 years ago, that I would be extolling the virtues of Chianti Classico Riserva. But times have changed and here I am, doing exactly that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler, Lauren Leatherby and Riley Mellen
title: Drone Captures Moment of Defiance, Which Israel Says Was Sinwar’s Last
description: In a war often seen from far away, the footage from an Israeli drone appears to capture a moment both pivotal and personal.
content: It was a pivotal moment of the war in Gaza and, in a surreal twist of modern warfare, Israel said it was filmed by a drone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Trump Defends Adams, Arguing Both Are Being ‘Persecuted’
description: Mayor Eric Adams, a Democrat, and Donald J. Trump, the Republican former president, are strange bedfellows as both face legal challenges.
content: Mayor Eric Adams’s federal indictment on corruption charges has left him with few political friends, but he has found a kindred spirit and a surprisingly steadfast ally in Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan McCarron and Jake Michaels
title: How Fugetsu-Do Survived the Evolution of Little Tokyo
description: Fugetsu-Do, a mochi store in the Little Tokyo neighborhood of Los Angeles, has existed for 121 years, with a lasting impact on its community.
content: Since 1903, a Japanese confectionery called Fugetsu-Do has been making mochi in the Little Tokyo neighborhood of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps Harris’s Time on Fox News and Trump’s on Univision
description: “Yes, both Kamala and Trump went into ‘the lion’s den’ this week — although they only got Trump there by telling him it was the name of a strip club,” Desi Lydic said on “The Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Huntington
title: Learning to Measure Time in Love and Loss
description: In this essay from 2013, a writer tries to appreciate the limits of his own life.
content: In celebration of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary this month, we published a special package of articles about the column’s history and impact. To learn about the origin of Modern Love, read about seven ways to love better, see how the longtime illustrator creates his images, and much more, go to nytimes.com/modernlove. In this space, as each week’s Modern Love column, we are republishing four “classic” essays from earlier years that especially moved us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mudslides, Misinformation and an Urgency to Vote in Western North Carolina
description: On the first day of early voting, residents of western North Carolina weighed which candidates would most help their yearslong recovery.
content: Carolyn Burgess, 71, drove on cracked and crooked roads in Black Mountain, N.C., to get to her polling place on Thursday, the state’s first day of early voting. Hurricane Helene had devastated her town, and its 8,500 residents were divided on the government response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: She Shared Her Notes with John Steinbeck. It was Her Novel’s Undoing.
description: Sanora Babb’s interviews about the Dust Bowl informed “The Grapes of Wrath.” The book’s success led to the cancellation of her own book contract. “Riding Like the Wind” tells her life story.
content: In 1938, when refugees fleeing the ravages of the Dust Bowl poured into California’s Central Valley, Sanora Babb worked in the migrant camps, setting up tents, planning dances, taking their children to makeshift clinics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 100 Raccoons
description: The Times reported on a woman who called 911 when a horde of raccoons showed up in her yard. Make up a story that explains how and why they got there.
content: Earlier this month, The New York Times reports, the Kitsap County Sheriff’s Office in Washington State received a call from a resident asking for help: A horde of around 100 aggressive raccoons had swarmed her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Nicholas Daniloff, 89, Dies; Reporter’s Arrest in Moscow Ignited a Firestorm
description: A veteran foreign correspondent during the Cold War, he was held on trumped-up espionage charges. He credited President Ronald Reagan with fighting for his release.
content: Nicholas Daniloff, an American news correspondent whose 1986 arrest in Moscow on trumped-up espionage charges ignited a political firestorm in the United States and an international crisis in the latter stages of the Cold War, died on Thursday at an assisted living facility in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Bruce Campbell on ‘Hysteria!’ and Why the Satanic Panic Never Ended
description: The Peacock horror comedy finds timeliness in a dark chapter of American history. “Satan was always an existential threat,” the actor said.
content: In 1981, Bruce Campbell knocked horror fandom’s socks off as Ash Williams, the iron-jawed demon fighter in “The Evil Dead,” Sam Raimi’s outré and now-beloved film about friends who battle unholy hell at a cabin in the woods. It was, it seems fair to say, a defining role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: U.S. Indicts 2 Linked to Oct. 7 Cyberattack on Israeli Warning System
description: The Justice Department has accused two Sudanese brothers of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure as well as preventing possibly lifesaving alerts from reaching Israelis as the Hamas attack unfolded.
content: It was early morning on Oct. 7, 2023, and Hamas fighters had just breached the Israeli border, when Ahmed Omer, a young Sudanese man with an aptitude for computers, launched a different kind of attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: At CBS, Everything Old Is New Again, Including ‘NCIS’
description: This week the network rolled out an “NCIS” spinoff, a “Young Sheldon” spinoff, a “Good Wife” spinoff and … “Matlock”?
content: CBS is reconvening this week, premiering a dozen of its dramas and comedies, including 10 of last season’s 15 most-watched scripted shows. You might dismiss the network’s dominance of the broadcast ratings as a case of being the top dog on a small playground, but the seven million to 10 million viewers each of those shows drew — before any streaming numbers were added — probably don’t care much about your opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat and Carlos Lozada
title: A Pollster Helps Us Manage Our Election Anxiety
description: It’s been a tumultuous campaign. Kristen Soltis Anderson helps us find stability in the polls.
content: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris have been neck and neck in the polls for weeks. But past elections have proved the polls wrong. Can we trust them this time? This week on “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts are joined by Kristen Soltis Anderson, a Republican pollster and Times Opinion contributor, to talk through what polls can — and can’t — tell us about how voting day will go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Money Market Rates Are Lower, Yes. But Compared to What?
description: Even with further Fed rate cuts likely, money market funds are a good alternative for stashing cash, and investors are still flocking to them, our columnist says.
content: When money market interest rates broke above 5 percent last year, it was a wake-up call for many investors who had grown accustomed to getting almost nothing for their money at banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 496
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Oct. 19, 2024
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: They Came for the Music. They Left With Draft Officers for Ukraine’s Army.
description: Men who attended the Kyiv concert of a popular rock band had their papers checked on the way out. Some were detained. Tickets to subsequent shows suddenly became available.
content: Okean Elzy is one of the top bands in Ukraine. It has a stadium rock style and songs with patriotic themes that for decades have provided the soundtrack to anti-Russia protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Shopping for a Good Loafer?
description: Start here.
content: The loafer, a shoe associated with country-club style and school uniforms, has been around for more than a century. A quality pair can hold up against various weather conditions and can be worn as easily with dresses and skirts as it can with pants and suiting. But with so many options on the market, how does one choose?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Hate Noisy Restaurants? Stick This in Your Ear.
description: Apple earbuds will soon be able to double as hearing aids, but those and others can already help you hear dining companions. Here’s how to use them.
content: Booking a table for two at Tao Downtown, I hesitated when I got to the box asking whether I had a special request. I did, but I wasn’t sure how it would go down. Would I be the first customer in history to ask for a noisy table?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, Wendy Dorr, Rowan Niemisto and Jon Pareles
title: Sophie’s Final Album
description: The visionary producer died in 2021. Her collaborators finished what she left behind.
content: In January 2021, the visionary hyperpop producer Sophie, known for her head-turning hooks and synthetically shiny electronic tracks, died in an accident. She had been in Athens climbing up to a balcony to get a better look at a full moon when she slipped and fell. She was only 34 years old.For many listeners, Sophie’s death brought home the ways her unique sonic vocabulary had moved so quickly from pop’s experimental fringe to the mainstream. Now three years after her passing, the album she left behind is complete. The Times’s chief pop music critic Jon Pareles spoke with some of her closest collaborators on how the project came together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Man Sentenced to Life in Prison for Transgender Woman’s Killing
description: The man, Daqua Lameek Ritter, was the first person in the country to be convicted of a federal hate crime based on gender identity.
content: A South Carolina man who was the first person in the United States to be convicted of a federal hate crime based on gender identity was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for the killing of a transgender woman in 2019, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts discussed former President Trump’s health and his bizarre town hall in Pennsylvania, as well as Vice President Harris’s appearance on Fox News.
content: With the general election just weeks away, the hosts discussed former President Trump’s health and his bizarre town hall in Pennsylvania, as well as Vice President Harris’s appearance on Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 18, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Sean Baker’s latest film, “Anora.”
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Sean Baker’s latest film, “Anora.”

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 19, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

author: By Patrick Ruffini
title: Forget Swing States. It’s These 21 Microcommunities That Could Decide the Election.
description: A look at the political microcommunities that could decide the 2024 presidential election.
content: A look at the political microcommunities that could decide the 2024 presidential election.

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Want to Understand America? Watch ‘Shark Tank.’
description: The show which premiered in the U.S. in 2009, has broadcast the stress of the Great Recession, the allure of Silicon Valley, the upheaval of the Covid pandemic and now, whatever this economy is.
content: The show which premiered in the U.S. in 2009, has broadcast the stress of the Great Recession, the allure of Silicon Valley, the upheaval of the Covid pandemic and now, whatever this economy is.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Israelis and Palestinians React to Assassination of Hamas Leader
description: While some Israelis expressed hope that the war might end soon, many Palestinians were doubtful that the death of Yahya Sinwar would lead to a cease-fire.
content: While some Israelis expressed hope that the war might end soon, many Palestinians were doubtful that the death of Yahya Sinwar would lead to a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Nikolay Nikolov, James Surdam, Laura Salaberry, Farah Otero-Amad and Dave Horn
title: Why Israel Targeted Yahya Sinwar
description: What does the killing of Yahya Sinwar, mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack, mean for Israel and Gaza? Ronen Bergman, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine who is based in Tel Aviv, explains.
content: What does the killing of Yahya Sinwar, mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack, mean for Israel and Gaza? Ronen Bergman, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine who is based in Tel Aviv, explains.

author: By Hannah Yi
title: Trump Jabs Harris for Not Attending Al Smith Charity Dinner
description: The annual Catholic charity event is known for inviting presidential candidates to lightheartedly roast each other.
content: The annual Catholic charity event is known for inviting presidential candidates to lightheartedly roast each other.
